title: 108_hr401
content: The "Koby Mandell Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section follows. The Congress finds that numerous American citizens have been victims of terrorism overseas, with some not receiving equal services from the US Government compared to other victims. Inadequate efforts and resources have been devoted to apprehending terrorists who have harmed American citizens abroad. The Palestinian Authority has not advertised monetary rewards for capturing terrorists in their areas, where many terrorists involved in the murders of Americans are free and even hold official positions. Some public sites in these areas are named after terrorists who killed Americans. An office should be established within the Department of Justice to capture all terrorists who have harmed American citizens overseas and provide equal treatment for American victims of overseas terrorism. An office in the Department of Justice will be established to capture terrorists who have harmed American citizens overseas and ensure equal treatment for all American victims of overseas terrorism. The President will establish an Office within the Department of Justice to oversee the Rewards for Justice program, offering rewards for capturing terrorists who harm American citizens overseas. The Office will advertise rewards in all countries where terrorists reside, display suspects' names and photographs on the website, and target specific organizations. The Office within the Department of Justice will provide notification to American victims of overseas terrorism, update them on efforts to capture terrorists, and submit reports to Congress. Additionally, the Office will collaborate with other US government agencies to restrict murderers from profiting from books or movies about their crimes. The Office within the Department of Justice will work to prevent terrorists who harm American citizens overseas from profiting from books or movies. It will also identify and report on terrorists serving in local police or security forces, requesting assistance be halted until they are removed from their positions. The Office within the Department of Justice will assess US indictments of terrorists who harm American citizens overseas and monitor public actions by governments related to terrorists. The Office within the Department of Justice will negotiate financial compensation for American citizens harmed by terrorist organizations that are now part of governing regimes with which the US maintains diplomatic relations. If terrorists who harmed Americans overseas are released from incarceration abroad, they may be eligible for further prosecution in the United States. The Office within the Department of Justice will coordinate with other government agencies to seek the transfer of terrorists who harmed Americans overseas to the United States for further prosecution. The Office will also ensure that these terrorists are treated as persona non grata, including denying them visas for entry, refraining from political and diplomatic contacts, and urging American visitors to avoid businesses owned or operated by them. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2003 and subsequent years as necessary to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
